user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of add_new_user_entry:
```c
static int
add_new_user_entry (const char *const username,
                    const char *const password,
                    const char *const realm,
                    int allow_area_1,
                    int allow_area_2)
{
  struct UserEntry *entry;
  enum MHD_Result res;

  if ((sizeof(user_ids) / sizeof(user_ids[0])) <= user_ids_used)
    return 0; /* No more space to add new entry */

  entry = user_ids + user_ids_used;

  entry->username = username;
  entry->realm = realm;

  res = MHD_YES;

  if (MHD_NO != res)
    res = MHD_digest_auth_calc_userhash (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5,
                                         username,
                                         realm,
                                         entry->userhash_md5,
                                         sizeof(entry->userhash_md5));
  if (MHD_NO != res)
    res = MHD_digest_auth_calc_userdigest (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5,
                                           username,
                                           realm,
                                           password,
                                           entry->userdigest_md5,
                                           sizeof(entry->userdigest_md5));

  if (MHD_NO != res)
    res = MHD_digest_auth_calc_userhash (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256,
                                         username,
                                         realm,
                                         entry->userhash_sha256,
                                         sizeof(entry->userhash_sha256));
  if (MHD_NO != res)
    res = MHD_digest_auth_calc_userdigest (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256,
                                           username,
                                           realm,
                                           password,
                                           entry->userdigest_sha256,
                                           sizeof(entry->userdigest_sha256));

  if (MHD_NO != res)
    res = MHD_digest_auth_calc_userhash (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256,
                                         username,
                                         realm,
                                         entry->userhash_sha512_256,
                                         sizeof(entry->userhash_sha512_256));
  if (MHD_NO != res)
    res =
      MHD_digest_auth_calc_userdigest (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256,
                                       username,
                                       realm,
                                       password,
                                       entry->userdigest_sha512_256,
                                       sizeof(entry->userdigest_sha512_256));

  if (MHD_NO == res)
    return 0; /* Failure exit point */

  entry->allow_area_1 = allow_area_1;
  entry->allow_area_2 = allow_area_2;

  user_ids_used++;

  return ! 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
if (MHD_NO != res)
    res = MHD_digest_auth_calc_userdigest (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256,
                                           username,
                                           realm,
                                           password,
                                           entry->userdigest_sha256,
                                           sizeof(entry->userdigest_sha256));

if ((sizeof(user_ids) / sizeof(user_ids[0])) <= user_ids_used)
    return 0; /* No more space to add new entry */

if (MHD_NO == res)
    return 0; /* Failure exit point */

if (MHD_NO != res)
    res = MHD_digest_auth_calc_userdigest (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5,
                                           username,
                                           realm,
                                           password,
                                           entry->userdigest_md5,
                                           sizeof(entry->userdigest_md5));

if (MHD_NO != res)
    res =
      MHD_digest_auth_calc_userdigest (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256,
                                       username,
                                       realm,
                                       password,
                                       entry->userdigest_sha512_256,
                                       sizeof(entry->userdigest_sha512_256));
explanation: I selected all places where control-flow could be deterministically fixed (constant-like assignments and conditional guards) and the explicit return points: (1) the initial capacity check that returns immediately, (2) the assignment res = MHD_YES together with each subsequent "if (MHD_NO != res)" guarded call that may be a tautological check at that program point or may cause later branches to be never taken, (3) the failure return guarded by res, and (4) the final "return ! 0;" which is an unconventional expression for a boolean true return and worth checking for clarity. These fragments are the spots most likely to hide unreachable code (e.g., conditions that are always true/false or returns that can never be reached). Other statements in the function — assignments to entry, username/realm, allow_area_1/2, user_ids_used++ and the pointer arithmetic — do not contain constant conditions or immediate returns and are plainly reachable along normal execution paths, so they do not need investigation for Rule 2.1 in the context of this function.
